firebends 161072574807 "2017-05-25 22:43:21 GMT" https://firebends.tumblr.com/post/161072574807/justsomeantifas-hey-so-remember-those-lawyers-we "justsomeantifas: Hey so remember those lawyers we all saw at the airports when Trumpâ€™s travel ban first came down? The ones that were working there for free to help represent the people being detained? Well one of the first non-profit groups that came down to the airport is in trouble.Â TheÂ ï»¿Northwest Immigrant Rights Project (NWIRP) has been issued aÂ â€œcease and desistâ€ letter by Jeff Sessionsâ€™ Department of Justice.Â  The DOJ is threatening disciplinary action if this non-profit continues to help immigrants
column2: refugees
column3: and asylum seekers.Â Some background information: One has NO right to counsel in immigration proceedings. That means you can be removed from your home
column4: jailed
column6: etc. without ever seeing a lawyer. Itâ€™s 100% legal and totally common
column7: so these lawyers work for free to ensure millions get the representation they deserve.Â The NWIRP represents children and refugees in immigration and asylum proceedings for free and they are one of thousands around the country.Â  Hereâ€™s an explanation to why the DOJ is issuing this cease and desist:  ï»¿â€œThe accusation is that because NWIRP provides advice and assistance to people in immigration proceedings without committing to full representation
column8: it is violating the rules. Itâ€™s a Kafkaesque system: The government wonâ€™t provide immigrant defendants with legal representation
column9: and they are allowed to get help for free only if they find a lawyer who will commit up-front to a case that will stretch on for years. Otherwise
column10: theyâ€™re not allowed to have any help at all
column11: are required to submit complex legal documents with no assistance
column12: and lawyers who try to help them will be sanctioned. Precisely because this would be a cruel and absurd result
column13: NWIRP and its peers around the country have had longstanding agreements with immigration officials that permit them to run asylum-assistance programs without committing to permanent representation. Attacking them now is a shockingly cynical move
column14: akin to sanctioning an emergency-room doctor for sewing up a bleeding patient without first promising to be their doctor for life. ï»¿ NWIRP doesnâ€™t know why it was singled out. But we do know that NWIRP has been at the forefront of resisting Trumpâ€™s travel ban. Its staff and volunteer lawyers were at SeaTac airport immediately after the White House launched the first Muslim ban
column15: and in March it sued to block the second Muslim ban. And NWIRP isnâ€™t alone; its nonprofit counterparts did the same at airports around the country
column16: leveraging law-school clinics and large-firm lawyers working pro bono. The DoJâ€™s suspiciously timed cease and desist letter sends a chilling message to exactly these groups
column17: and to volunteer attorneys. This attack by the government on a legal services-provider for immigrants could dissuade law firms from letting their lawyers volunteer for these cases
column18: scaring those firms away by convincing them that immigration-related projects are too risky pro-bono projects.â€  The NWIRP has successfully been granted a restraining order
column19: so right now they are still able to help immigrants who need legal advice but their work is at risk. They are now filing a lawsuit to defend itself from the move
column20: the move that will set precedent to other non-profits who do similar work. Â Â  If you would like to support them you can join them as a volunteer or donate.Â  You can also follow regular updates on what theyâ€™re doing and the case against the DOJ on their Facebook and Twitter. Â  (source) (source) " False text

column3: there was Lilly
column4: who was brought to Texas at the age 15 by a couple of American executives at a technology company. They promised her an American education and a path out of poverty for her family in Jamaica
column5: in exchange for working as a live-in nanny for their three children. Instead
column7: they cut off her communication with her family and the outside world. For 15 years
column8: her mobility was restricted. She was not allowed to leave the house unaccompanied or talk to any of the neighbors. And she was never paid.And there was Karmo
column9: who came from Nepal to a Virginia suburb
column11: to work for an Indian diplomat. Upon arrival
column12: she was forced to work from early morning until late at night
column13: isolated and prohibited from talking to other people. Karmoâ€™s passport was confiscated by her employer and she was told she could be picked up by the police if she complained. For both Lilly and Karmo
column14: the extreme economic hardships of their families left them vulnerable to false promises of a better life; once in America
column17: and lack of other jobs and options made it hard for them to leave.Slavery doesnâ€™t just happen in a vacuum
column18: as some perversion from the bigger economic context that people live in. Deep poverty and few options for economic mobility make a person vulnerable to slavery. Language and cultural barriers

column1: firebends 160626919392 "2017-05-13 18:16:01 GMT" https://firebends.tumblr.com/post/160626919392/meet-the-sex-workers-replacing-cops-in "wocinsolidarity: In most countries around the world
column2: sex workers are criminalized by police officers. In Sandinista-run Nicaragua
column3: sex workers are replacing police officers. Last January
column4: French filmmaker Florence Jaugey released a documentary about the Sunflowers of Nicaragua
column5: a woman-led sex worker collective serving as community mediators for the socialist government. Today
column6: the documentary is receiving praise across Latin America
column7: one of the most dangerous regions in the world for sex workers. â€œWe wanted to show the world that we are not the image they have of us
column8: â€ Sunflowers of Nicaragua member Maria Elena Davila told El Nuevo Diario.  â€œWe are capable women
column10: and we are also contributing to justice in our country. This documentary tells our story.â€ In 2009
column11: members of the Sunflowers of Nicaragua began organizing against discrimination and violence within their communities. They did this with the intention of gaining the trust of their communities in order to win mass support for their primary demand: the judicial integration and unionization of sex workers across the country. Their strategy worked.  In 2015
column12: Nicaraguaâ€™s Supreme Court of Justice asked members of the collective if they wanted to work as judicial facilitators in Managua
column14: the sex workers are accredited and have licenses signed by the Supreme Court of Justice to mediate small conflicts in their communities
column15: which include problems between relatives and neighbors.  The program is intended to â€œreduce the weight on the police and the judicial systemâ€ while integrating sex workers into Nicaraguaâ€™s judicial system
column16: Jaugey told Economy in a recent interview. â€œItâ€™s a unique case in the world that the justice authorities have given this responsibility to these women
column17: â€ Jaugey said.  â€œBut also the success of this film is not just due to Nicaragua and the state of the law here
column18: itâ€™s also due to the goodwill of these women.â€ The Sunflowers of Nicaragua has also been accepted by the socialist governmentâ€™s Confederation of Self-Employed Workers
column19: granting them legal union status. The collective
column20: which aims to organize Nicaraguaâ€™s estimated 14
